In 1977, Kissinger left his position as Secretary of State but remained active in global affairs as a scholar and advisor. In 1995, he received the Nobel Peace Prize, though it is worth noting that it was awarded to him jointly with former UN Secretary-General Le Duc Tho, and the award sparked a considerable debate.

As National Security Advisor (1969-1975) and later as Secretary of State, Kissinger pursued a policy of détente with the Soviet Union and engaged in secret negotiations with China that led to President Nixon's historic visit in 1972.

He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1973, though the decision remains controversial. In retirement, Kissinger has remained an influential commentator and has continued to write books and essays on foreign policy.

Born on May 27, 1923, in Fürth, Germany, Kissinger's early life was shaped by the tumultuous events of the era, including the rise of Adolf Hitler and the Nazi regime. In 1938, when Kissinger was only 15, his family emigrated to the United States, where he was granted citizenship in 1943.

Educated at Harvard University, where he studied history and political science, Kissinger began his career as a journalist, later turning his attention to academia. He was an instructor of international relations at Harvard from 1954 to 1962 and also taught at several other esteemed universities worldwide.

In 1969, President Richard Nixon appointed Kissinger as the United States Secretary of State, and later as National Security Advisor, making him one of the most powerful figures in the administration. During his tenure, Kissinger played a central role in shaping American foreign policy, particularly in relation to the Cold War and the conflicts in Southeast Asia. During his tenure as Secretary of State, Kissinger also played a central role in the opening of diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China and the development of the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) with the Soviet Union.
